docs.lead_paragraph: Whether or not the Supreme Court strikes down the health care law’s individual mandate, the rule might matter less than its advocates believe.

headline.seo: A Health Care Mandate That May Not Matter - Economic Scene

docs.abstract: Eduardo Porter Economic Scene column suggests that the forthcoming Supreme Court ruling on the provision in the Affordable Care Act requiring every American to buy health insurance may matter less than its advocates believe and, if it is struck down, it may not gut the law; contends that whether Americans embrace universal coverage as a desirable goal for a rich industrial society will prove to be critical.
docs.snippet: Whether or not the Supreme Court strikes down the health care law’s individual mandate, the rule might matter less than its advocates believe.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Companies have been slowly adding workers for more than two years. But pink slips are still going out in a crucial area: government. In California, the governor is threatening to eliminate 15,000 state jobs. When school begins in Cleveland this fall, more than 500 teachers probably will be out of work. And in Trenton -- which has already cut a third of its police force, hundreds of school district employees and at least 150 other public workers -- the only way the city will forestall the loss of 60 more firefighters is if a federal grant comes through.

headline.main: Layoffs Hitting Public Workers; Recovery Is Hurt

docs.abstract: Governors and state legislatures are keeping a tight rein on spending, despite the fact that state revenues have started to recover, and as a result, job losses in the public sector have become the single biggest drag on the recovery in many areas; fourteen states plan to resolve their budget gaps by reducing aid to local governments, which will likely exacerbate public sector losses. Photos, Chart (M)

byline.original: By SHAILA DEWAN and MOTOKO RICH

docs.lead_paragraph: At Harvard Law School in 1990, President Obama found himself lovingly mocked by his peers for relentlessly promoting the exotic story of a search for racial identity that later became the theme of his best-selling book, ''Dreams From My Father.'' ''My mother was a backup singer for Abba. They were good folks,'' a student parody of Mr. Obama joked. In Chicago, ''I discovered I was black, and I have remained so ever since.''

headline.main: Political Memo: Obama Biography Brings New Scrutiny to President's Own Memoir

docs.abstract: Political Memo; David Maraniss's new biography Barack Obama: The Story claims to document the many ways in which Pres Obama's youthfully constructed narrative in his memoir Dreams From My Father appears to be contradicted by the people and events in his life; book follows reporting in The New York Times and elsewhere over the past six years that has sometimes called into question parts of Obama's life story. Photos (M)
docs.snippet: At Harvard Law School in 1990, President Obama found himself lovingly mocked by his peers for relentlessly promoting the exotic story of a search for racial identity that later became the theme of his best-selling book, ''Dreams From My Father.''    ...

headline.main: New Book Raises Questions About Obama's Memoir
headline.print_headline: Political Memo: Obama Biography Brings New Scrutiny to President’s Own Memoir

docs.abstract: A new book by a Washington Post reporter could raise further questions about how closely the President Obama's telling of his life hews to reality.
docs.snippet: A new book by a Washington Post reporter could raise further questions about how closely the President Obama's telling of his life hews to reality.

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans fortunate enough to have a job are often overqualified and find that wages and benefits are down, leaving many unable to meet their expenses.

headline.seo: Many American Workers Are Underemployed and Underpaid
headline.main: Lost in Recession, Toll on Underemployed and Underpaid
headline.print_headline: Lost in Recession, Toll on Underemployed and Underpaid

docs.abstract: Many middle- and working-class Americans fortunate enough to have a job during the recession are struggling with lower pay, decreased benefits and shorter hours, leaving those affected unable to meet their expenses.
docs.snippet: Americans fortunate enough to have a job are often overqualified and find that wages and benefits are down, leaving many unable to meet their expenses.

byline.contributor: Robbie Brown contributed reporting from Atlanta; Malia Wollan from El Cerrito, Calif.; and Ian Lovett from Los Angeles.

docs.lead_paragraph: Electronic medical records, by uploading data automatically to state health departments, are enabling officials to identify and track outbreaks more quickly than ever.

headline.seo: States Using Electronic Medical Records to Track Epidemics
headline.main: Fast Access to Records Helps Fight Epidemics
headline.print_headline: Fast Access To Records Helps Fight Epidemics

docs.abstract: Electronic medical records, which upload data automatically to state health departments, are enabling officials to identify and track outbreaks of diseases and infections more quickly than ever.
docs.snippet: Electronic medical records, by uploading data automatically to state health departments, are enabling officials to identify and track outbreaks more quickly than ever.

docs.lead_paragraph: People infected with H.I.V. have more heart attacks and have them earlier in life, researchers have found.

headline.seo: Heart Attacks Are Much More Frequent in H.I.V. Patients
headline.main: Heart Trouble Early and Often in H.I.V. Patients
headline.print_headline: Heart Trouble Early and Often In H.I.V. Patients

docs.abstract: Emerging research shows that people infected with HIV are at an increased risk of heart attack and suffer attacks earlier in life; Dr Priscilla Y Hsue, San Francisco cardiologist who led study published in recent issue of the Journal of the American College of Cardiology, argues that HIV-positive patients need aggressive screening for coronary disease and aggressive treatment of blood pressure and cholesterol disorders.
docs.snippet: People infected with H.I.V. have more heart attacks and have them earlier in life, researchers have found.

headline.main: Trust in Government, Declining With Cuts

docs.abstract: Declining confidence in institutions and cutting funds for those institutions can be a self-perpetuating cycle.
docs.snippet: Declining confidence in institutions and cutting funds for those institutions can be a self-perpetuating cycle.

docs.lead_paragraph: Hired on freelance contracts, foreign language teachers at Italian universities are treated like second-class citizens. These foreign lecturers have won cases in courts, but changes have been slow.

headline.main: Foreign Instructors Fighting for Equality at Italian Universities
headline.print_headline: Foreign Instructors Fighting for Equality at Italian Universities
